newsitem.title: JAPAN: OPEC quota should not be raised -- Qatar minister.
newsitem.headline: OPEC quota should not be raised -- Qatar minister.

text.p: OPEC's quotas should not be raised because of Iraq's expected return to the international oil market, Qatar's Energy and Industry Minister Abdullah bin Hamad al-Attiyah said on Thursday.
"I believe they (quotas) should not be raised. Iraq is coming to the market and to achieve a balance between demand and supply, quotas should be rolled over," he told Reuters in an interview.

The minister said talks between three Japanese trading houses and Qatar regarding their taking a partial stake in a second liquefied natural gas (LNG) project in the country will be concluded by the end of October.
He said a portion of the project will be sold to the Japanese trading houses, Sumitomo Corp, Itochu Corp and Nissho Iwai.
Qatar General Petroleum Corp has a 70 percent stake in the project and Mobil Corp the remaining stake.
At the last Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting in June, there were suggestions the quotas could be raised at the next meeting in November.
Quotas for the 13-member oil cartel were kept steady at the June meeting except for an additional 800,000 barrels-per-day for Iraq's expected return to the market.

Iraq's military foray in the north, where Kurdish rebels enjoyed a measure of self-rule since the end of the 1991 Gulf War, prompted punitive U.S. missile strikes and warnings that its long-awaited oil-for-food deal could be further delayed.

The accord was finally signed in May and would allow Iraq, crippled by six years of trade sanctions following its 1990 invasion of Kuwait, to export $2 billion worth of oil over six months to buy food and medicine and make limited war reparations.

Energy and Industry Minister Abdullah bin Hamad al-Attiyah is in Japan for a ceremony marking the first liquefied natural gas LNG vessel to carry Qatari term gas cargoes to Japan. He will be here until Saturday.
Sumitomo Corp, Nissho Iwai Corp and Itochu Corp have been seeking to acquire a combined 10 percent stake in the Ras Laffan LNG Co project, traders said.
The minister declined to say how large the stake would be. The project is expected to start production in 1999.
